definition: to signal the musicians (in Chinese opera, by prolonging a spoken word before attacking a song)/(coll.) to challenge
to shout/to call/to order/to ask/to be called/by (indicates agent in the passive mood)
board/plank/plate/shutter/table tennis bat/clappers (music)/CL:塊|块[kuai4]/accented beat in Chinese music/hard/stiff/to stop smiling or look serious

sentences.english: We could, at long last, have a trump card to play against Darwin.
sentences.chinese: 最終，我們就有了自己的王牌，可以叫板達爾文。
本雅明甚至在那時就已對我的懷疑論叫板。

sentences.english: This arrangement which would last for ten years should help Microsoft in its aim of challenging the long permanents of Google.
sentences.chinese: 該次合作將長達十年，合作讓微軟有底氣叫板谷歌。

sentences.english: You never hear Cotto calling me out.
sentences.chinese: 你聽到過庫託叫板我嗎？

definition: to be on an equal footing
peer competition/to function as rivals/to make claims as an equal
to adopt confrontational posture/to meet head-on/to compete
to give orders/to spread news or rumors/to leak certain information intentionally
to speak conceited nonsense/to come out with arrogant claptrap
(dialect) to come to blows/to have a row
see 撕破臉|撕破脸[si1 po4 lian3]
to get into a dispute with
